part.narration: Yuki stares into a mirror. From the other side stares royalty likely to be saved by galaxy-trekking plumbers. The benefit of being blonde, it seems. Yuki turns around. The harsh bright of superfluous diode-light blinds. Whirring fans are under the whim of screaming fans. There are six other people in the room. Throughout the windowless palace echoes primitive home entertainment system noise. Yuki's fringe slaps her.
part.line: I can't believe this is the state of my job-friends.
What kind of costumed LAN party is this?
The "retro" game you guys are playing isn't even a good one.

choice.line: It's too real! Realistic things are not fun!
You take turns! Strange timings are not fun!
It's too complex! Complex things are not fun.

part.line: We play video games to escape life.
Must we look for engaging experiences from them?
Here, we need not worry about looking lame or high-class or tough or worldly or careless or real.
Play with us. Play with us. Play with us. Play with us. Play with us.
Fun blah blah simple blah blah gameplay blah gameplay gameplay blah gameplay
blah blah fantasy blah relax blah realism bad blah abstraction bad blah complexity bad—
How dare you seek solely for comfort from Art!
How dare you claim to have invented happiness!
There is a full gamut of emotion that our artists are leaving untouched,
part.narration: This faux light is too much. These costumes are too much. These opinions are too much. These people are not enough. This is not her basement. Yuki hyperventilates.Yuki points to the basement exit.She rushes to the non-constricting outside air.
part.line: And so, our wills are weakened as we button-mash in graves.
All of us, seals and monkeys skipping to the abyss of mediocrity.
